docs.lead_paragraph: Backed by millions of dollars in financial support from Paul G. Allen, a founder of Microsoft, a team of scientists has set out to pinpoint the roughly 20,000 genes responsible for building and operating the human brain. From there, the scientists will put together a highly detailed atlas of the mammalian brain and make it available to the public through an online database. To accomplish that goal, they are relying heavily on the genome of the common mouse, which genetically bears remarkable similarities to humans.

headline.main: Public Atlas Of the Brain In the Works

docs.abstract: Paul G Allen, on of Microsoft founders, is backing large-scale project to pinpoint estimated 20,000 genes responsible for building and operating human brain; project, called Allen Brain Atlas, hopes to make all information available through online database, which would allow collaboration from around world; mouse brain is genetically similar to human brain and mapping of mouse gene expression could answer many questions about humans; project is led by Dr Mark Boguski, Allen Institute for Brain Science director; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Backed by millions of dollars in financial support from Paul G. Allen, a founder of Microsoft, a team of scientists has set out to pinpoint the roughly 20,000 genes responsible for building and operating the human brain. From there, the scientists...

docs.lead_paragraph: Diuretics, often used to treat people with high blood pressure, may also help elderly people prevent hip fractures, researchers reported yesterday. The findings grew out of a longstanding research project called the Rotterdam Study. For the hip research, scientists followed 7,891 people 55 and older for as long as nine years, keeping track of their use of thiazide diuretics and the incidence of hip fractures.
docs.abstract: Rotterdam Study, research project tracking 7,891 people 55 and older for up to nine years, shows participants who use diuretics for one year or more suffer half as many hip fractures as those who do not take them; theorize that diuretics reduce amount of calcium lost through urination (S)
docs.snippet: Diuretics, often used to treat people with high blood pressure, may also help elderly people prevent hip fractures, researchers reported yesterday.   The findings grew out of a longstanding research project called the Rotterdam Study.    For the hip...

docs.lead_paragraph: The medical oddballs today who feel shunned by mainstream practitioners can take comfort, for better or worse, in a new mini-series on medical history that makes heroes of fanatical scientists of yesteryear. To say the least, they lacked tact. Imagine the reaction to Dr. Ignaz Semmelweis, a surly Hungarian, who called his colleagues murderers because they refused to wash their hands between autopsies and delivering babies. He was onto something (hygiene) but lacked people skills. Dr. Semmelweis died in a mental hospital, but hand-washing eventually caught on.

headline.main: Medical History's Oddballs Go Prime Time

docs.abstract: Mavericks, Miracles and Medicine, new mini-series for History Channel, tells story of early medical pioneers; writer and director Jeffrey Tuchman comments; Dr Ignaz Semmelweis, proponent of hand-washing, Andreas Vesalius, infamous grave-robbing father of anatomy, and microscope inventor Antoni van Leeuwenhoek are some of founders of modern medicine who are discussed in show; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: The medical oddballs today who feel shunned by mainstream practitioners can take comfort, for better or worse, in a new mini-series on medical history that makes heroes of fanatical scientists of yesteryear. To say the least, they lacked tact.    ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Being on a high school sports team does not make a student less likely to use drugs, engage in risky sexual behavior or otherwise act carelessly, researchers report. But girls who are team members and who are also physically active may be less likely to take these kinds of risks, researchers from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention say. Their report, in The Archives of Pediatrics & Adolescent Medicine, said schools and communities should work to ease barriers to girls' involvement in team sports, especially girls who are members of minority groups.
docs.abstract: Dr Nancy D Brener, Dr Kimary Kulig and Tim McManus, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention researchers, report in Archives of Pediatrics and Adolescent Medicine that girls exhibit significant reductions in risky behavior, including drug and alcohol abuse, when involved in team sports; students who are active but not on team do not show changes in behavior; male behavior was not influenced by team sport participation; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: Being on a high school sports team does not make a student less likely to use drugs, engage in risky sexual behavior or otherwise act carelessly, researchers report.    But girls who are team members and who are also physically active may be less...

docs.lead_paragraph: When life is not going so smoothly and people reach for goodies full of fat and sugar, they are doing more than surrendering to cravings. Comfort foods like chocolate cake and ice cream literally blunt the body's response to chronic stress, scientists reported last week. The finding, published in the online edition of The Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, confirms what many people know firsthand. Eating calorie-rich food seems to calm the nerves, but eating too much can lead to obesity, depression and more stress.

headline.main: Comfort Foods Switch Off Stress, Scientists Find

docs.abstract: Dr Norman Pecoraro, University of California (San Francisco) postdoctoral fellow, publishes research in Proceedings of National Academy of Sciences online version, that shows that eating comfort foods blunts effects of stress on body; research, carried out on rats, finds that feeding chronically stressed rats sugar calms them down; also finds that people with more abdominal fat are better able to cope with and shut down chronic stress; abdominal fat, however, is also linked with higher rates of other life threatening diseases; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: When life is not going so smoothly and people reach for goodies full of fat and sugar, they are doing more than surrendering to cravings. Comfort foods like chocolate cake and ice cream literally blunt the body's response to chronic stress,...

docs.lead_paragraph: When the first wave of sick marines arrived at Andrews Air Force Base at 4:30 a.m. on Sept. 7, they were greeted by a medical team wearing the protective gear reserved for deadly infections -- N95 masks, gowns, gloves and booties over their shoes. The 31 marines had become suddenly ill aboard their ships, the Iwo Jima and Carter Hall, days after suffering countless mosquito bites during two weeks ashore in Liberia in mid- to late August. Some marines ran fevers up to 105 degrees. Many were anemic. Some had diarrhea.

headline.main: Medical Teams Fight Outbreak of Malaria Among Marines

docs.abstract: Fifty-four out of 625 American troops deployed in Liberia for two weeks last summer have developed falciparum malaria, one of most deadly forms of disease; infected Marines, from ships Iwo Jima and Carter Hall, were sent to Andrews Air Force Base and then on to Bethesda Medical Center, for diagnosis and treatment; Dr Gregory J Martin, Bethesda Naval Medical Center program director of infectious disease fellowships led military medical team; process of caring for Marines is described; possible reasons for outbreak, including ineffective anti-malarial drugs, are explored; last major military outbreak was in Somalia in early 1990's; photos (L)
docs.snippet: When the first wave of sick marines arrived at Andrews Air Force Base at 4:30 a.m. on Sept. 7, they were greeted by a medical team wearing the protective gear reserved for deadly infections -- N95 masks, gowns, gloves and booties over their shoes.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: A strikingly large number of Americans have failed to catch the exercise bug, and the effects are showing up not only in their expanding girth but also in their health -- and death -- statistics. American women are particularly sedentary. According to the 2000 National Health Interview Survey, 72 percent of women and 64 percent of men get no regular exercise.

headline.main: Exercise Is a Habit; Here's Why to Pick It Up

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses two new studies showing how physical activity benefits overall health and weight; Dr Anne McTiernan, Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center (Seattle) researcher, directs study that shows how risk of various life threatening conditions is reduced in direct proportion to increase in physical activity; study also finds that those women who take hormone replacements receive benefits of increased activity as well; Dr John M Jakicic of University of Pittsburgh's Physical Activity and Weight Management Research Center finds calorie reductions paired with exercise improved health and weight management, but neither degree of exercise intensity nor duration directly effected results; suggests that exercising moderately for one hour consistently each day is more effective than shorter or inconsistent sessions; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: A strikingly large number of Americans have failed to catch the exercise bug, and the effects are showing up not only in their expanding girth but also in their health -- and death -- statistics.    American women are particularly sedentary....

docs.lead_paragraph: Minors can easily buy cigarettes today if they turn to the Internet, a new study reports. Researchers say that when four children, ages 11 to 15, tried to buy cigarettes from 55 vendors in 12 states, they succeeded more than 90 percent of the time.
docs.abstract: Dr Kurt M Ribisl, University of North Carolina School of Public Health researcher, publishes study in Journal of American Medical Association that demonstrates how easily minors can purchase cigarettes online; finds that four children ages 11 to 15 succeeded 90 percent of time in their attempt to buy cigarettes; various online preventive measures are found to be ineffective in stopping young people from making purchases; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Minors can easily buy cigarettes today if they turn to the Internet, a new study reports.    Researchers say that when four children, ages 11 to 15, tried to buy cigarettes from 55 vendors in 12 states, they succeeded more than 90 percent of the...

docs.lead_paragraph: Even with the cool weather that has arrived in the last week, Colorado health officials are still telling residents not to let down their guard against the mosquito-borne West Nile virus. Colorado has been the hardest hit state this year, with nearly 1,500 people infected, and it has had the highest number of deaths, with 27 reported so far. It has also cataloged a few possible symptoms like a nonitchy rash that doctors had not previously seen here.

headline.main: West Nile Virus Is Still a Threat as Fall Nears

docs.abstract: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports that nationwide infections of West Nile Virus are nearly double number reported last year; Colorado reports largest number of cases while western plains states is hardest hit region; agency stresses need to continue vigilance against infection well into colder weather; although majority of cases reported are mild, there has been increase in severe cases, which can cause paralysis, meningitis, encephalitis or coma; several specific cases are discussed; uncertainties about long-term effects of disease cause health care workers additional concern; photo; map (M)
docs.snippet: Even with the cool weather that has arrived in the last week, Colorado health officials are still telling residents not to let down their guard against the mosquito-borne West Nile virus.     Colorado has been the hardest hit state this year, with...

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite a government recommendation that people with asthma receive annual flu vaccinations, only about a third do so, a new study reports. Among people ages 18 to 49 the figure is even lower -- about one in five, researchers write in the journal Chest. For those 50 to 64, the rate is about 45 percent. Higher vaccination rates were associated not just with being older, but also with being better educated.
docs.abstract: Researchers writing in journal Chest have determined that people with asthma are at greater risk for influenza complications and should get flu vaccine; data was gathered from federal health surveys between 1991 and 2001 (S)
